prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Copy of ALESS 73.1_[NII]122
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Detect the [NII] 122 micron line in ALESS 73.1

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
Our anticipated [NII] 122um line flux is based on the detected [NII] 205 line flux which has a FWHM of 230 km/s (Nagao 2012) [9]. We assume an [NII]122/[NII]205 flux ratio ~ 2. Figure 1 (middle) shows that this ratio will be sufficient for all but the lowest average ionized gas densities (<10^1.75 cm^-3).
Observations by (de Breuck 2014) [10], show [CII] distributed over ~0.64''. If we assume the [NII] is cospatial, the full emission will fit into a single band 8 beam and we do not need to worry about surface brightness dimming.
We assume our [NII] 122 line is Gaussian with a similar FWHM. Since this is a detection experiment and we don't need detailed line velocity profiles, we will use the FWHM spectral width for our detection. We set requested sensitivites to achieve a S/N of 5. Even if the average ionized gas density is significantly lower, we should still be able to detect [NII] 122 with slightly reduced S/N. A S/N of 3 will be achieved if the true [NII]122/[NII]205 ratio is as low as 1.2 - significantly lower than the average value ~1.5 measured across the Carina Nebula (Oberst 2011) [8], or our own galactic disk (Wright 1991) [22].
With our requested line RMS we will also easily detect the underlying continuum. Our estimate of the continuum flux density comes from the continnum in the [CII] observations (de Breuck 2014) [10].

We have chosen a correlator setup that maximizes the total continuous bandwidth to ensure we capture all of the velocity components of our source. We set the correlator to operate with 1.875 GHz bandwidth and 31.25 MHz resolution since our lines are very large ~100's km/s
Our representative baseband is centered on our line, with one adjacent base band on either the low or high frequency side and two more basebands in the opposite side band to increase continuum sensitivity. The basebands in the sideband containing the line provide ~2630 km/s of continuous spectral coverage, covering either (-658 to +1973 km/s) or (-1973 to +658 km/s).
We request a compact configuration with a synthesized beam size ~0.7'' to minimize over resolving the source resulting in surface brightness dimming (larger beam size is also acceptable).

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Copy of ALESS 73.1_[OI]145
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Detect the OI 146 micron line in ALESS 73.1

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
Our anticipated [OI] 145um line flux is based on the detected [CII] line flux which has a FWHM of 160 km/s (de Breuck 2014) [10]. The [CII] line is a better than the [NII] 205 line for estimating [OI] emission since both species arise largely in PDRs. We assume an [OI]145/[CII] flux ratio ~ 0.037. In their sample of 28 extragalactic sources detected with ISO, (Vasta 2010) [11] find that 90% have [OI]145/[CII] > 0.037. We use this factor as our scaling ratio.
Observations by (de Breuck 2014) [10], show [CII] distributed over ~0.64'' with a FWHM of 160 km/s. If we assume the [OI] is cospatial, the full emission will fit into a single band 7 beam and we do not need to worry about surface brightness dimming.
We assume our [OI] 145 line is Gaussian with a similar FWHM. Since this is a detection experiment and we don't need detailed line velocity profiles, we will use the FWHM spectral width for our detection. We set requested sensitivites to achieve a S/N of 5.
With our requested line RMS we will also easily detect the underlying continuum. Our estimate of the continuum flux density comes from the continnum in the [CII] observations (de Breuck 2014) [10].

We have chosen a correlator setup that maximizes the total continuous bandwidth to ensure we capture all of the velocity components of our source. We set the correlator to operate with 1.875 GHz bandwidth and 31.25 MHz resolution since our lines are very large ~100's km/s
Our representative baseband is centered on our line, with one adjacent base band on either the low or high frequency side and two more basebands in the opposite side band to increase continuum sensitivity. The basebands in the sideband containing the line provide ~3140 km/s of continuous spectral coverage, covering either (-2355 to +785 km/s) or (-785 to +2355 km/s).
We request a compact configuration with a synthesized beam size ~0.7'' to minimize over resolving the source resulting in surface brightness dimming (larger beam size is also acceptable).

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Copy of TNJ0924_[NII]205
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Detect the [NII] 205 micron line in TN J0924-221

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
Our anticipated [NII] 205um line flux is scaled from the predicted [CII] line on the northern clump. Based on a set of ~250 local sources in the Great Observatories All-sky LIRG Survey (GOALS), in which both [CII] and [NII] 205 were detected, we assume a minimum [NII] 205/[CII] line luminosity ratio of 0.04. This cut-off encompasses ~95 of the GOALS sample (Diaz-Santos 2013) [21].
Since this is a detection experiment and we don't need detailed line velocity profiles, we will use the FWHM spectral width (assumed to match that of CO) for our detection. We set requested sensitivites to achieve a S/N of 5.
With our requested line RMS we will also detect the underlying continuum. Our estimate of the continuum flux density comes from the observed 205 um continuum on the fainter, southern, clump. Based on this we should be able to detect the continuum (again) in this observation, both on the southern clump and the northern clump which is 2.3 x brighter.

We have chosen a correlator setup that maximizes the total continuous bandwidth to ensure we capture all of the velocity components of our source. We set the correlator to operate with 1.875 GHz bandwidth and 31.25 MHz resolution since our lines are very large ~100's km/s
Our representative baseband is centered on our line, with one adjacent base band on either the low or high frequency side and two more basebands in the opposite side band to increase continuum sensitivity. The basebands in the sideband containing the line provide ~3670 km/s of continuous spectral coverage, covering either (-2750 to +920 km/s) or (-920 to +2750 km/s).
We request a compact configuration with a synthesized beam size ~0.7'' to minimize over resolving the source resulting in surface brightness dimming (larger beam size is also acceptable).

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Copy of TNJ0924_[CII]158
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Detect the [CII] 158 micron line in TN J0924-221

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
Our anticipated [CII] 158um line flux is based on the detected CO (1-0) line flux which has a FWHM ~ 300 km/s (Klamer 2005) [19]. We assume a conservative ratio for star forming galaxies, [CII]/CO(1-0) > 2600.
Our continuum observations at 205 um show two clumps unresolved at ~8". Therefore we anticipate very little surface brightness dimming from over resolution. Based on the distribution of the 205 um continuum, we believe the northern clump is responsible for ~70% of the FIR emission. We tailor our requested line sensitivities to detect emission coming from this source, scaling our total, CO-predicted line intensities by 70%.
We assume our [CII] line is Gaussian with a similar FWHM. The [CII] line is predicted to be very bright in this source, detectable in a short amount of time. Due to the finite calibration time and overheads associated with each observation, we set a minimum on source time of five minutes. This allows us to reach a sensitivity of 390 uJy over our 300 km/s FWHM, achieving a S/N on our anticipated line ~60. Note that if the southern Lyman alpha emitter component is responsible for ~30% of the total line emission (as our continuum map suggests,) then we will also detect [CII] in the southern clump.
With our requested line RMS we will also easily detect the underlying continuum. Our estimate of the continuum flux density comes from the observed 205 um continuum on the fainter, southern, clump. Based on this we should be able to detect the continuum (again) in this observation, both on the southern clump and the northern clump which is 2.3 x brighter.

We have chosen a correlator setup that maximizes the total continuous bandwidth to ensure we capture all of the velocity components of our source. We set the correlator to operate with 1.875 GHz bandwidth and 31.25 MHz resolution since our lines are very large ~100's km/s
Our representative baseband is centered on our line, with one adjacent base band on either the low or high frequency side and two more basebands in the opposite side band to increase continuum sensitivity. The basebands in the sideband containing the line provide ~3670 km/s of continuous spectral coverage, covering either (-2750 to +920 km/s) or (-920 to +2750 km/s).
We request a compact configuration with a synthesized beam size ~0.7'' to minimize over resolving the source resulting in surface brightness dimming (larger beam size is also acceptable).

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Copy of TNJ0924_[OI]146
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Detect the [OI] 146 micron line in TN J0924-221

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
Our anticipated [OI] 145um line flux is scaled from the predicted [CII] line on the northern clump. We assume an [OI]145/[CII] flux ratio ~ 0.037. In their sample of 28 extragalactic sources detected with ISO, (Vasta 2010) [11] find that 90% have [OI]145/[CII] > 0.037. We use this factor as our scaling ratio.
We will use the FWHM spectral width for our detection. We set requested sensitivites to achieve a S/N of 5.
With our requested line RMS we will also easily detect the underlying continuum.

We have chosen a correlator setup that maximizes the total continuous bandwidth to ensure we capture all of the velocity components of our source. We set the correlator to operate with 1.875 GHz bandwidth and 31.25 MHz resolution since our lines are very large ~100's km/s
Our representative baseband is centered on our line, with one adjacent base band on either the low or high frequency side and two more basebands in the opposite side band to increase continuum sensitivity. The basebands in the sideband containing the line provide ~3670 km/s of continuous spectral coverage, covering either (-2750 to +920 km/s) or (-920 to +2750 km/s).
We request a compact configuration with a synthesized beam size ~0.7'' to minimize over resolving the source resulting in surface brightness dimming (larger beam size is also acceptable).

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Copy of TNJ0924_[NII]122
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Detect the [NII] 122 micron line in TN J0924-221

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
Our anticipated [NII] 122um line flux is scaled from the predicted [CII] line on the northern clump. We assume an [NII] 122/[CII] ratio of 0.08. In an archival ISO sample of 12 extragalactic sources detected in [CII] and [NII] 122, 9 exceed this ratio (Vasta 2010) [11].
We will use the FWHM spectral width for our detection. We set requested sensitivites to achieve a S/N of 5.
With our requested line RMS we will also easily detect the underlying continuum. Our estimate of the continuum flux density comes from the observed 205 um continuum on the fainter, southern, clump. Based on this we should be able to detect the continuum (again) in this observation, both on the southern clump and the northern clump which is 2.3 x brighter.

We have chosen a correlator setup that maximizes the total continuous bandwidth to ensure we capture all of the velocity components of our source. We set the correlator to operate with 1.875 GHz bandwidth and 31.25 MHz resolution since our lines are very large ~100's km/s
Our representative baseband is centered on our line, with one adjacent base band on either the low or high frequency side and two more basebands in the opposite side band to increase continuum sensitivity. The basebands in the sideband containing the line provide ~2840 km/s of continuous spectral coverage, covering either (-2130 to +710 km/s) or (-710 to +2130 km/s).
We request a compact configuration with a synthesized beam size ~0.7'' to minimize over resolving the source resulting in surface brightness dimming (larger beam size is also acceptable).

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: With a modest ALMA census of four bright far infrared, fine structure lines ([NII] 122 and 205 um, [OI] 146 um, and [CII] 158 um) we will characterize the gas in ionized and photon dominated regions in two star forming galaxies at z>4.5. We will establish the density of the ionized and photo-dissociated gas regions, characterize the intensity of the far-UV radiation, and constrain the numbers of Lyman continuum photons. This will provide new insight into the first chapters of galaxy evolution by determining star formation rates, the spatial extent of star formation, and nitrogen to carbon abundance ratios which will give the first unambiguous indications of metallicity in galactic ionized regions within ~1.5 Gyr of the birth of the Universe.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Cosmology and the High Redshift Universe
